file_metadata.title: A comprehensive conceptual and computational dynamics framework for Autonomous Regeneration Systems

chunks.text: This paper introduces a new conceptual and computational framework for damage detection and regeneration in multicellular structures, aiming to achieve complete and accurate regeneration from any damage. The model is demonstrated on an artificial organism with head, body, and tail structures, each composed of a stem cell and differentiated cells. Tissues are represented as Auto-Associative Neural Networks (AANNs) with local interactions, while stem cells function as self-repair networks with long-range interactions. An "Information Field" concept stores minimal pattern information for access by stem cells in extreme damage scenarios. Stem cells monitor tissue integrity via entropy, triggering damage detection and repair upon violation. The model regenerates at two levels: tissue regeneration with intact stem cells, and stem cell network restoration with missing tissues and stem cells. This framework offers a new perspective on regeneration, potentially benefiting regenerative medicine and bio-robot development.
chunks.chunk_summary: A new computational model for regeneration is presented, featuring AANNs for tissues, self-repairing stem cell networks, and an Information Field for robust pattern restoration.

chunks.text: Regeneration, the recovery of lost body parts, is a widespread but incompletely understood phenomenon in nature.  Animals exhibit varying regenerative capacities, from snails regrowing heads to planarians regenerating entire bodies. While molecular mechanisms are being uncovered, the algorithms governing complex anatomical regeneration remain a knowledge gap. This study aims to develop a conceptual framework for complete regeneration in a simple organism like planaria, potentially informing self-repairing bio-robots and contributing to bio-inspired computing.
chunks.chunk_summary: Regeneration is a complex process with varying capacity across species, and understanding its algorithms is crucial for advancing regenerative medicine and bio-inspired computing.

chunks.text: Planaria, known for their remarkable regenerative abilities, can regrow an entire body from a tiny fragment.  Stem cells called neoblasts migrate to the blastema to regenerate missing parts, guided by anterior-posterior (A/P) polarity.  Despite the known involvement of cell interactions and communication, the precise mechanisms of planarian regeneration, including polarity establishment, remain unclear.  This study focuses on the algorithmic mechanisms of regeneration, aiming to contribute to a better understanding of pattern formation and regeneration in planaria.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planaria's ability to regenerate from tiny fragments, guided by A/P polarity and stem cells, makes them a key model for understanding regeneration mechanisms.

chunks.text: Existing algorithmic models of regeneration have limitations in explaining whole-body regeneration, requiring excessive information storage and computational burden.  These models struggle with stopping regeneration at the right time, leading to overgrowth.  This study builds upon a previous autonomous self-repair system for simple tissue regeneration, aiming to extend it to complex pattern regeneration.  The goal is to develop a computationally efficient and biologically realistic model that mimics planarian regeneration, including complete and accurate regeneration from small fragments.
chunks.chunk_summary: Existing regeneration models have limitations in computational efficiency and biological realism, prompting the need for improved models like the one proposed in this study.

chunks.text: Fundamental questions about regeneration remain unanswered, including how a small body fragment knows the whole pattern, where pattern information is stored or generated, and how damage is sensed and communicated.  This study aims to address these questions by extending a previous tissue self-repair model to a whole-organism regeneration system.  The goal is to develop a computational framework that mimics planarian regeneration, including complete and accurate regeneration from any fragment, concurrent tissue regeneration, and minimal computational burden.
chunks.chunk_summary: Key questions about pattern information storage, damage sensing, and regeneration control remain open, motivating the development of a comprehensive regeneration model.

chunks.text: Regeneration is viewed as a biological computing process.  Bessonov et al.'s model based on signal distribution and cellular memory has limitations in large organisms due to signal decay and computational cost.  Tosenberger et al.'s model, with global and local submodels for stem cell and tissue regeneration, cannot handle stem cell damage and has limitations in large tissues.  Ferreira et al.'s agent-based model requires excessive packet storage and communication.  De et al.'s model using neural and non-neural cell interactions is more biologically realistic but requires excessive pruning.  Gerlee et al.'s genetic algorithm model requires predefined growth areas.  These models highlight the need for more efficient and realistic regeneration algorithms.
chunks.chunk_summary: Existing regeneration models, while offering valuable insights, suffer from limitations in computational cost, biological realism, and handling complex scenarios like stem cell damage.

chunks.text: Planarian regeneration involves re-establishing polarity, with Wnt and BMP signaling pathways playing a role.  Recent research suggests that neural directionality can set biochemical gradients for polarity.  Robotic self-repair systems, inspired by stem cells, can reconstruct damaged structures but often on a smaller scale.  Further research is needed on how these systems can learn new patterns and reorganize into resilient structures, mimicking biological evolution.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian polarity establishment involves signaling pathways and neural directionality, while robotic regeneration systems offer insights but need further development for learning new patterns.

chunks.text: The previous work presented an autonomous tissue self-repair system using a neural network framework.  A circular tissue with a stem cell and differentiated cells is represented as a bi-directional graph (AANN).  Global sensing (GS) using entropy detects damage, while local sensing (LS) using local feedback connections identifies the exact damage location.  The stem cell then migrates and regenerates missing cells.  This model achieves complete regeneration with minimal computation but requires retaining pattern information in the tissue, limiting its ability to handle extreme damage.  This study extends this model to address this limitation and handle more complex tissue patterns and multiple tissue systems.
chunks.chunk_summary: The previous model used AANNs, global and local sensing, and stem cell regeneration, but had limitations in handling extreme damage due to reliance on existing tissue information.

chunks.text: This study extends the previous tissue repair model to a whole-organism regeneration system.  New concepts are introduced: "smart" stem cells with virtual information fields storing minimum pattern information, and a stem cell network with a collective information field.  The model combines circular, triangular, and rectangular tissue shapes, each with a smart stem cell, to form a virtual organism.  The smart stem cell network monitors and repairs itself, while differentiated cells form AANNs.  This system aims to mimic planarian regeneration, including whole-pattern regeneration from small fragments and concurrent tissue regeneration with minimal computation.
chunks.chunk_summary: The proposed model extends the previous work by introducing smart stem cells, information fields, and a stem cell network to achieve whole-organism regeneration.

chunks.text: The original tissue repair model consists of a circular tissue with a stem cell and differentiated cells.  Cells have polar coordinates with Brownian noise.  The tissue is represented by an AANN with local connections.  Global communication between the stem cell and all differentiated cells maintains tissue integrity, while local communication between neighboring cells manages the pattern.  Global sensing uses entropy to detect damage, triggering local sensing in the AANN to identify the exact location.  The stem cell then migrates and regenerates missing cells through asymmetric cell division.
chunks.chunk_summary: The base model uses a circular tissue with a stem cell and AANN-represented differentiated cells, employing global and local sensing for damage detection and stem cell regeneration.

chunks.text: Global sensing uses entropy (Eq. 1) as a measure of communication intensity between the stem cell and differentiated cells.  A change in entropy indicates damage, prompting the stem cell to identify the general damage region.  Local sensing activates the AANN in the identified region.  Each interior cell in the AANN has four neighbors and fires (output 1) only if all neighbors are present (Eq. 2).  Border cells fire if three neighbors are present.  This allows the system to identify the damage boundary.  The stem cell migrates to the damage location and regenerates missing cells until the original pattern is restored.
chunks.chunk_summary: Global sensing uses entropy to detect damage, while local sensing utilizes AANN neighbor rules to pinpoint the damage location, guiding stem cell migration and regeneration.
